title: Vacation Rights
legalBasis: Workers' Statute (Royal Legislative Decree 2/2015) Article 38; Spanish Constitution Article 40.2 on paid periodic holidays; ILO Convention 132 on annual holidays with pay; EU Working Time Directive 2003/88/EC; Applicable collective agreements
summary:
Annual paid vacation is a fundamental employment right protecting worker health, wellbeing, and work-life balance. Article 38 of the Workers' Statute establishes that all workers are entitled to a minimum of 30 calendar days of paid annual vacation, which cannot be replaced by monetary compensation except upon termination of employment. This minimum is one of the most generous in Europe, reflecting Spanish legal recognition that extended rest periods are essential for recovery from work stress and for maintaining physical and mental health. The right to vacation is not merely a benefit granted at employer discretion but a legally mandated entitlement that accrues automatically with employment.

In the hospitality sector, vacation scheduling presents particular challenges due to the need for continuous operations, seasonal demand peaks, and the requirement that most vacations occur during summer months when personal preferences align but business needs are greatest. These challenges create tension between worker preferences for summer vacation, business needs for adequate staffing during peak periods, and legal requirements that vacation schedules be determined by mutual agreement or, failing agreement, according to fair procedures established by collective agreements or judicial practice. Understanding vacation rights, calculation methods for partial years, scheduling procedures, carry-over and expiration rules, and compensation upon termination is essential for both workers and employers.

Vacation serves multiple purposes: physiological recovery from work stress and fatigue, psychological restoration of mental energy and motivation, social reconnection with family and friends, and practical management of personal affairs difficult to address during working periods. Research consistently demonstrates that vacation reduces stress, improves health indicators, enhances work performance after return, and increases overall life satisfaction. Yet, many hospitality workers face pressures that undermine vacation benefits: difficulty obtaining preferred vacation dates, fragmentation of vacation into short periods preventing extended recovery, work contact during vacation, and fear that taking vacation will be viewed negatively. Legal protections exist to combat these pressures, but enforcement requires workers understanding and asserting their rights.
keyPoints: Minimum annual vacation entitlement is 30 calendar days (approximately 22 working days excluding Sundays and public holidays)
Vacation entitlement accrues proportionally during the first year of employment based on months worked
Vacation period must be known at least two months in advance, providing predictability for personal planning
At least one vacation period must comprise at least two consecutive weeks, allowing extended recovery
Vacation schedule is determined by mutual agreement between employer and worker or, failing agreement, by procedures in collective agreement
Vacation cannot be replaced by monetary compensation during active employment (only upon termination)
Unused vacation does not automatically carry over to following year; use-it-or-lose-it principle applies unless specific circumstances prevent usage
Workers on sick leave during scheduled vacation can request rescheduling of vacation days lost to illness
Upon termination, unused vacation days must be compensated at daily salary rate or taken before departure if feasible
Collective agreements may provide more generous vacation entitlements (over 30 days) but cannot provide less

sections.heading: 1. Vacation Entitlement and Calculation
sections.content:
Article 38.1 of the Workers' Statute establishes the minimum annual vacation entitlement at 30 calendar days. This is significantly more generous than minimums in many countries and reflects Spanish cultural values around work-life balance and family time. Calendar days means all days including weekends and holidays that fall within the vacation period. A vacation of 30 calendar days typically comprises approximately 22 working days (Monday-Friday), as weekends and any public holidays falling within the period are already non-working days and do not require separate vacation allocation. Collective agreements can provide more generous vacation (35 calendar days, 40 calendar days, etc.) but cannot reduce below the statutory 30-day minimum.

Vacation accrues based on time worked. For workers employed for a complete calendar year, the full 30-day entitlement applies. For workers who start employment mid-year or who terminate employment before year-end, vacation is prorated: (months worked ÷ 12 months) × 30 days = calendar days of vacation entitlement. Calculation is typically based on complete months worked. For example, a worker who starts employment on March 15 and works through year-end has worked approximately 9.5 complete months, entitling them to (9.5 ÷ 12) × 30 = approximately 24 calendar days vacation for that partial year.

The reference period for calculating annual vacation is typically the calendar year (January 1 - December 31), though some collective agreements or contracts use different reference periods such as contract anniversary dates or business years. If a different reference period applies, it should be clearly specified in the employment contract. Workers should understand which reference period applies to their vacation calculation, as this determines when vacation accrues, when it must be used (vacation typically must be used within the year it is earned unless specific circumstances justify deferral), and how partial-year calculations are made upon starting or ending employment.

subsections.heading: 1.1 Vacation During First Year of Employment
subsections.content:
During the first year of employment, vacation accrues proportionally based on months worked. Different practices exist regarding when first-year vacation can be taken. Some employers allow new workers to take vacation proportional to time worked at any point (for example, after three months, take approximately 7-8 days vacation representing the accrued portion). Other employers prefer that new workers complete a full year before taking vacation, then taking the full annual entitlement. The latter approach is not legally required; workers are entitled to take accrued vacation even during the first year unless the employment contract or collective agreement explicitly provides otherwise.

Practical considerations for first-year vacation include: coordination with probation periods (typically 2-6 months depending on role level), during which either party can terminate without notice or cause, so scheduling vacation during probation creates risk of vacation interruption; learning and integration needs, as very new workers are still learning roles and taking early vacation may disrupt training and integration; and mutual convenience, where employers may request that new workers delay vacation until more established, and workers may prefer to accumulate more days before taking vacation. These considerations can inform negotiation but do not override the legal right to proportional vacation.

subsections.heading: 1.2 Part-Time Workers' Vacation Entitlement
subsections.content:
Part-time workers are entitled to the same vacation duration as full-time workers — 30 calendar days annually. This is a critical equality protection: vacation entitlement is based on employment relationship, not hours worked. A part-time worker employed for 20 hours weekly receives 30 calendar days vacation, the same as a full-time worker employed 40 hours weekly. During vacation, the part-time worker receives vacation pay calculated on their part-time hours and salary, but the duration (30 days) is identical.

This equal vacation entitlement reflects recognition that vacation serves recovery, social, and personal functions that are not proportional to working hours. A part-time worker needs extended time away from work for these purposes just as a full-time worker does. The legal equality principle ensures that part-time workers, who are disproportionately women, are not disadvantaged regarding vacation rights. Some collective agreements provide even more generous vacation for all workers, and these enhanced entitlements apply equally to part-time workers.

sections.heading: 2. Vacation Scheduling and Mutual Agreement
sections.content:
Article 38.2 establishes that vacation period is determined by mutual agreement between employer and worker, with the period to be known at least two months in advance. The mutual agreement requirement respects both parties' legitimate interests: workers have personal preferences for vacation timing (family events, school holidays for workers with children, personal trips), while employers have operational needs (adequate staffing, avoiding concentration of vacations during peak business periods). Good faith negotiation seeking accommodation of preferences while meeting operational needs is the ideal approach.

In practice, vacation scheduling procedures vary. Common approaches include: annual vacation planning process where all workers submit vacation preferences for the coming year (typically in November-December for the following calendar year), management develops a vacation calendar attempting to accommodate preferences while maintaining adequate staffing, and the proposed calendar is communicated for consultation before finalization; first-come first-served systems where workers request specific dates throughout the year, with earlier requests receiving priority; seniority systems where workers with more service years get preference in selecting vacation dates; or rotation systems where preference ordering rotates annually (workers who had low priority in selecting dates one year receive high priority the following year).

Whatever procedure is used, the vacation calendar must be confirmed and communicated at least two months before vacation commencement. For example, if a worker is scheduled for vacation in August, this must be confirmed by no later than June. The two-month notice requirement provides predictability allowing workers to make personal plans (book travel, arrange family gatherings, schedule activities) with confidence. Last-minute vacation cancellations or changes by employers are prohibited absent extraordinary circumstances (force majeure situations genuinely requiring all-hands operational response), and even then, workers may be entitled to compensation for any losses incurred from canceled plans.

subsections.heading: 2.1 Resolving Vacation Scheduling Disputes
subsections.content:
When employer and worker cannot reach mutual agreement on vacation scheduling, Article 38.2 provides that 'in the event of disagreement, the Labor Court will set the dates' ensuring vacation is scheduled fairly. In practice, judicial resolution of vacation disputes is rare as it is time-consuming and by the time court determination occurs, the disputed vacation period may have passed. Most disputes are resolved through alternative mechanisms: collective agreement procedures specifying how scheduling conflicts are resolved (seniority, rotation, lottery); worker representatives or unions mediating between workers and management to find compromise solutions; or management imposing vacation schedules within reasonable bounds of fairness when genuine agreement is unattainable.

Management-imposed vacation schedules must still be reasonable and non-arbitrary. Consistently denying a specific worker's vacation preferences while accommodating others, scheduling vacation at times deliberately inconvenient to the worker (forcing vacation during personal important events if known), or using vacation scheduling punitively (difficult workers get worst vacation slots) constitute unfair treatment potentially constituting harassment or discrimination. Workers experiencing systematically unfair vacation scheduling should document the pattern and file grievances through worker representatives, unions, or labor courts. Fair scheduling does not guarantee everyone gets first preferences, but does require that preferences are considered, operational justifications for denials are genuine, and burdens of less-desirable dates are distributed equitably across workers.

subsections.heading: 2.2 Mandatory Vacation Periods
subsections.content:
Some collective agreements or employer policies establish mandatory vacation periods when the entire establishment or specific departments close for vacation (common in August in Spanish hospitality). Mandatory vacation periods are legal if specified in applicable collective agreements or established through proper consultation procedures. Workers must take vacation during the mandated closure period; the alternative would be unpaid leave as no work is available. From workers' perspective, mandatory vacation periods limit personal choice but provide certainty and can facilitate coordination with family members' vacations (particularly school holidays).

From employers' perspective, coordinated vacation periods simplify scheduling, allow complete facility maintenance during closure, and can reduce operational costs during traditionally slow periods. However, employers cannot simply declare mandatory vacation without legal basis. If the collective agreement establishes the right to determine vacation scheduling by mutual agreement (as the Workers' Statute does), unilateral imposition of mandatory vacation may be challengeable unless the agreement or established practice supports it. Workers who object to mandatory vacation periods should check collective agreement provisions and consult worker representatives about whether imposition is legally supported.

sections.heading: 3. Vacation Fragmentation and Minimum Continuous Period
sections.content:
Article 38.2 specifies that 'at least one of the vacation periods must comprise at least two consecutive weeks.' This provision ensures that workers receive at least one extended vacation period allowing meaningful recovery and disconnection from work. Research on vacation benefits shows that very short vacations (2-3 days) provide limited restoration, while vacations of at least two weeks produce significant health and wellbeing benefits. The mandatory two-week continuous period prevents employers from fragmenting annual vacation into numerous short periods that meet the total days requirement but fail to provide adequate recovery.

The remaining vacation days (after the mandatory two-week continuous period) can be split into shorter periods if mutually agreed or as specified in collective agreements. Common patterns include: two weeks in summer and one week in winter/spring; two weeks in summer plus scattered long weekends throughout the year; or three separate one-week periods plus scattered days. The key is that whatever fragmentation occurs, at least one two-week continuous period must be included. Collective agreements may provide more generous continuous period requirements (for example, requiring one three-week period or two separate two-week periods), and such provisions bind employers.

Fragmentation of vacation, even within legal limits, can undermine recovery benefits. Multiple short vacations require more transition time (preparing for departure, readjusting on return) relative to vacation time enjoyed, and do not allow the deep restoration that extended vacations provide. Workers should advocate for vacation scheduling that optimizes recovery benefits: taking longer consolidated periods rather than numerous short fragments where possible, scheduling vacation at times when genuine rest is possible (not immediately before or after major work projects requiring preparation or follow-up), and using vacation for genuine rest and personal activities rather than feeling obligated to use vacation for work-related or obligatory activities.

subsections.heading: 3.1 Public Holidays and Vacation Interaction
subsections.content:
Public holidays (días festivos) falling within a vacation period are not consumed as vacation days and do not reduce vacation entitlement. For example, if a worker takes two weeks vacation (14 calendar days) and a public holiday falls within this period, the worker is entitled to either extend vacation by one day or take the holiday as a separate day off later. This principle recognizes that public holidays are independent rest entitlements separate from annual vacation. The practical implementation varies: some employers automatically extend vacation periods when holidays fall within them; others credit back holiday days to be taken separately; some collective agreements specify which approach applies.

Weekends falling within vacation periods are counted as vacation days because the statutory entitlement is expressed in calendar days, which include weekends. This is why 30 calendar days vacation comprises approximately 22 working days (Monday-Friday). The distinction is important: public holidays do not count against vacation entitlement; weekends do count but are implicit in the calendar day calculation. Workers should verify when scheduling vacation that public holidays are handled correctly and not inappropriately consumed as vacation days.

subsections.heading: 3.2 Vacation and Work Contact
subsections.content:
Vacation is intended as rest time fully disconnected from work. Workers on vacation should not be expected to perform work tasks, attend meetings, respond to work emails or calls, or otherwise remain engaged with work. The right to digital disconnection (desconexión digital) established in Spanish law explicitly protects workers' right to not respond to work communications outside working hours, which certainly includes vacation periods. Employers contacting workers on vacation creates stress, prevents recovery, and undermines vacation benefits.

Exceptions for genuine emergencies may exist (critical situations requiring specific knowledge or authority possessed only by the vacationing worker), but these should be extremely rare. Employers should ensure: adequate coverage arrangements so vacationing workers' responsibilities are handled by others; clear communication to all staff that workers on vacation should not be contacted except absolute emergencies; documentation of any emergency contacts so that if challenged, the employer can demonstrate genuine necessity; and consideration of compensating workers for vacation interruptions (rescheduling affected vacation days, providing extra rest days, or monetary compensation). Workers who experience systematic work contact during vacation undermining rest should document this and raise it as violation of rest rights and digital disconnection rights.

sections.heading: 4. Vacation and Illness Interaction
sections.content:
Spanish and European case law establishes that workers who fall ill during scheduled vacation have the right to reschedule vacation days lost to illness. The rationale is that vacation serves recuperation and rest functions that cannot be achieved while ill; illness during vacation frustrates the vacation purpose. To exercise this right, workers must: notify the employer immediately upon falling ill during vacation; obtain medical certification documenting the illness and its duration; request rescheduling of the vacation days affected by documented illness; and provide medical documentation to the employer promptly. The employer must allow rescheduling of the documented illness days to another period by mutual agreement.

This right has significant implications. Workers who become ill on the day before scheduled vacation and obtain medical certification documenting incapacity can have their vacation period postponed (the vacation does not start while they are on sick leave; it starts when they recover and medical clearance is provided). Workers who fall ill mid-vacation can have the remaining vacation days from the illness onset rescheduled. The right prevents situations where workers lose vacation benefits due to bad luck timing of illness. However, the right requires proper medical documentation; workers cannot simply claim to be ill without certification and demand vacation rescheduling.

Conversely, workers already on sick leave (incapacidad temporal) when previously scheduled vacation dates arrive have the right to take the vacation instead of continuing on sick leave, or to reschedule vacation to after recovery. This right accommodates different situations: some workers prefer to take scheduled vacation even while recovering, particularly if vacation plans involve family who adjusted schedules to coordinate; other workers prefer to continue medical recovery and reschedule vacation to when they can fully enjoy it. The choice should be the worker's, in consultation with medical advice, not imposed by the employer.

subsections.heading: 4.1 Documentation Requirements for Vacation-Illness Interaction
subsections.content:
To reschedule vacation due to illness, proper medical documentation is essential. Workers should: notify the employer on the first day of illness during vacation (phone call or email stating 'I have fallen ill during vacation and will be providing medical certification'); obtain medical attention from public or private healthcare providers and request certification documenting the illness, diagnosis if appropriate, dates of incapacity, and medical clearance for return to work; submit medical documentation to the employer promptly (within days of obtaining it, not waiting until after vacation period ends); and formally request rescheduling of specific vacation days documented as lost to illness.

Employers may verify medical documentation but cannot refuse rescheduling if proper documentation is provided. Disagreements about whether documentation is sufficient can be resolved through company medical services (if available) reviewing the submitted documentation, or ultimately through labor courts if the employer refuses rescheduling despite apparently adequate documentation. Workers should retain copies of all medical documentation and correspondence regarding vacation rescheduling, as these are essential evidence if disputes arise.

subsections.heading: 4.2 Maternity/Paternity Leave and Vacation
subsections.content:
Workers on maternity leave, paternity leave, or other parental leaves retain their annual vacation entitlement. Vacation accrues normally during parental leave periods. Workers often have unused vacation at the time parental leave commences (particularly women who may begin maternity leave suspension in the final weeks of pregnancy). These unused vacation days are preserved and can be taken after return from parental leave by agreement with the employer. Some workers negotiate to take accumulated vacation immediately following parental leave, extending time at home with the new child.

Parental leave periods do not consume vacation days. The sixteen-week maternity/paternity leave (as per current law) is separate from the 30-day annual vacation. Workers are entitled to both full maternity/paternity leave and full annual vacation. Employers cannot reduce vacation entitlement for workers who take parental leave. Some collective agreements provide additional benefits such as extra vacation days in the year a child is born, recognizing the demands of new parenthood. Workers should verify that their vacation entitlement is not improperly reduced due to parental leave and should advocate for coordination of parental leave and vacation that supports family needs.

sections.heading: 5. Vacation Carry-Over, Expiration, and Compensation
sections.content:
The general principle under Spanish labor law is that vacation must be taken during the year it is earned (or within the relevant reference period if other than calendar year). Vacation does not automatically carry over to the following year. This 'use it or lose it' principle incentivizes actual vacation usage, preventing accumulation of excessive unused vacation that could create workforce management complications and would defeat vacation's rest and recovery purpose. However, this principle is subject to important exceptions and qualifications.

Vacation can carry over to the following year if the worker was unable to take vacation during the accrual year due to circumstances beyond their control: extended sick leave during the vacation year preventing vacation usage; maternity or paternity leave occupying much of the year; or employer actions that prevented vacation (refusing all vacation requests, failing to confirm vacation schedule, establishing vacation calendar that did not provide the worker's entitled days). In these circumstances, the worker does not lose vacation entitlement but can claim it in the following year. The burden is typically on the worker to demonstrate that inability to use vacation was due to circumstances beyond their control, not personal choice to defer vacation.

European Court of Justice case law establishes that workers cannot lose vacation due to employer actions. If an employer fails to enable vacation usage (not establishing vacation calendar, denying vacation requests without justification, creating workplace culture where vacation usage is discouraged), the worker retains entitlement and can claim accumulated vacation, potentially for multiple years if the situation has persisted. Spanish implementing law following ECJ case law establishes expiration periods: unused vacation can be claimed up to 18 months after the accrual year ends, after which it expires if not claimed. Workers in situations where vacation has been systematically denied should document this and file claims for accumulated vacation entitlement before expiration occurs.

subsections.heading: 5.1 Vacation Compensation Upon Termination
subsections.content:
Upon termination of employment (resignation, dismissal, contract expiration), unused vacation must be compensated. Article 38.1 explicitly states that vacation cannot be replaced by monetary compensation 'except in the case of contract termination.' The compensation is calculated as: (unused vacation days ÷ calendar days per year) × annual gross salary = vacation compensation, or equivalently, daily salary rate × unused vacation days. Daily salary rate includes prorated extra payments and regular salary complements.

For example, if annual salary is €21,000 and the worker has 10 unused calendar days of vacation at termination, compensation is (10 ÷ 365) × €21,000 = approximately €575. This amount should appear in the final settlement (finiquito) documentation provided at termination. Workers should verify vacation compensation calculation in settlement documents: are unused vacation days correctly calculated based on annual entitlement minus vacation actually taken; is the daily salary rate calculated correctly including all salary components; and is the mathematical calculation correct. Disputes over vacation compensation in final settlement are common and should be addressed before signing settlement acceptance documents.

subsections.heading: 5.2 Vacation Buy-Out Prohibition
subsections.content:
Article 38.1's prohibition on replacing vacation with monetary compensation during active employment is absolute. Employers cannot offer to pay workers to forgo vacation; workers cannot request payment instead of vacation. Any such agreements are void. The prohibition protects worker health by ensuring that rest periods are actually taken, not converted to money. It prevents situations where economic pressure might lead workers to forgo needed rest in exchange for additional pay, harming long-term health.

Some workers, particularly those with economic pressures, might prefer payment over vacation. The legal prohibition is paternalistic in nature, reflecting a societal judgment that health protection through mandatory rest supersedes individual autonomy to trade rest for pay. Workers may disagree with this policy but cannot legally contract around it. The only exception is termination, where requiring vacation usage may be impractical (particularly if termination is immediate or short-notice) and compensation is provided instead.

sections.heading: 6. Enforcement and Remedies
sections.content:
Workers experiencing vacation rights violations — denial of vacation, inadequate vacation duration, improper scheduling, unpaid vacation compensation at termination, or retaliation for taking vacation — should pursue enforcement through available channels. Internal resolution begins with written complaint to employer specifying the violation and requesting correction. For scheduling disputes, involve worker representatives or unions who may mediate between worker and management. For calculation disputes, document the calculation showing entitlement and request explanation of any discrepancy. Many vacation disputes can be resolved at this stage if employer is responsive and the issue stems from misunderstanding rather than willful violation.

Labor inspectorate complaints are appropriate for clear statutory violations: denying minimum 30-day vacation entitlement, refusing to establish vacation calendar with required two-month notice, failing to provide at least one two-week continuous period, or refusing rescheduling of vacation lost to documented illness. Inspectors can investigate, order corrections, and impose administrative fines for violations. Complaints should specify the violation, provide documentation (employment contract, vacation requests, employer responses, payslips showing vacation taken), and cite applicable legal provisions and collective agreement terms.

Labor court claims are appropriate for individual compensation disputes: unpaid vacation compensation in final settlement, compensation for vacation days wrongly denied, or damages from vacation violations causing harm (canceled non-refundable travel plans due to employer's last-minute vacation cancellation, for example). Claims should calculate amount sought (number of vacation days × daily salary rate, plus consequential damages if applicable), provide evidence (documentation of entitlement, vacation requests and responses, settlement documents, receipts for canceled plans if claiming consequential damages), and present legal basis for claim. Time limits apply (typically one year for salary-related claims from date due); workers should not delay filing claims if informal resolution is unsuccessful.

subsections.heading: 6.1 Vacation Rights and Contract Termination
subsections.content:
Disputes over vacation compensation upon termination are extremely common. Final settlement (finiquito) documents presented at termination include multiple calculations: unpaid salary, unused vacation compensation, prorated extra payments if termination occurs mid-year, overtime compensation if applicable, and potentially termination indemnity (for dismissals). Workers often sign finiquito documents without fully verifying calculations, then discover errors later. Best practice is: request finiquito documents with sufficient time before signing (at least 24-48 hours to review carefully, consult union or lawyer if needed); carefully verify each component of the calculation including unused vacation days calculation; do not sign if calculations are unclear or appear incorrect — request clarification or correction; and if signing under protest (disagree with calculations but employer insists on immediate signing), clearly note on finiquito document 'signed without accepting calculation accuracy, reserves right to claim additional amounts' (firmado sin aceptar exactitud del cálculo, se reserva el derecho a reclamar cantidades adicionales).

Signing finiquito does not absolutely preclude later claims if miscalculations or omissions are proven, but it creates evidential difficulty as employer will argue that worker accepted the settlement. Workers who discover after signing that vacation compensation was miscalculated can file labor claims within applicable time limits, but will need to overcome the presumption created by having signed acceptance. Clear reservation of rights at time of signing strengthens later claims. Better still is verifying calculations before signing or refusing to sign until corrections are made.

subsections.heading: 6.2 Collective Action on Vacation Issues
subsections.content:
Vacation scheduling and usage issues often affect multiple workers and may reflect systemic employer practices (systematically denying vacation, unfair scheduling procedures, workplace culture discouraging vacation usage). Collective responses can be more effective than individual complaints. Unions and worker representatives can: negotiate improved vacation scheduling procedures in collective agreement revisions; file collective grievances about unfair vacation policies or systematic denials; represent multiple workers in disputes about vacation rights; and organize workplace campaigns promoting vacation usage and challenging cultures of presenteeism where vacation is stigmatized.

Where workplace culture discourages vacation usage (expectations that dedicated workers don't take vacation, subtle retaliation against workers who take full entitlement, competitive presenteeism dynamics), individual workers may feel unable to take vacation despite legal entitlement. Collective efforts to normalize vacation usage — management taking vacation and communicating about it positively, union campaigns promoting vacation as a right and health necessity, worker representatives monitoring vacation usage rates and challenging low usage as potential indication of pressure not to take vacation — can shift cultures toward healthier vacation usage patterns. Sustainable vacation rights enforcement requires both individual assertiveness and collective cultural change supporting vacation usage as normal and positive rather than shirking.

checklists.title: Annual Vacation Planning Checklist
items: Verify your annual vacation entitlement (30 calendar days minimum, check collective agreement for any enhancements)
Determine the vacation reference period for your employment (typically calendar year)
Calculate vacation accrued if employed for partial year: (months worked ÷ 12) × 30 days
Review employer's vacation scheduling procedure (annual planning process, first-come first-served, seniority, rotation)
Submit vacation preferences according to employer procedure and deadlines
Ensure at least one period of at least two consecutive weeks (14 calendar days) is included in request
Negotiate with employer if initial calendar does not accommodate important personal preferences
Verify vacation calendar is confirmed at least two months before each vacation period commencement
Document vacation schedule (dates confirmed by employer in writing) for personal planning
Plan personal activities (travel, family events) after vacation is confirmed, not before
Track vacation days taken throughout year to ensure full entitlement is used
If unable to use full vacation due to illness or other qualifying circumstances, request carry-over or rescheduling

checklists.title: Vacation Usage and Documentation Checklist
items: Confirm vacation dates with employer in writing before making non-refundable commitments (travel, bookings)
Submit any required vacation request forms or follow employer procedures for recording vacation
Ensure you are not contacted for work matters during vacation (exercise digital disconnection right)
If you fall ill during vacation, notify employer immediately and obtain medical certification documenting illness
Submit medical documentation promptly and request rescheduling of vacation days lost to documented illness
Track actual vacation days taken (start and end dates, total calendar days) for verification against annual entitlement
Verify that payslips during vacation period show full salary payment (vacation is paid at full salary)
At year end, calculate total vacation taken vs. annual entitlement to identify any unused days
If unused vacation remains due to circumstances beyond your control, request carry-over to following year with documentation of reasons
Maintain personal vacation records (requests, approvals, dates taken) for verification and potential disputes

checklists.title: Vacation Compensation at Termination Checklist
items: Calculate unused vacation days at time of termination (annual entitlement minus days actually taken)
Request preliminary calculation of finiquito (final settlement) before signing, ideally 24-48 hours in advance
Verify vacation compensation calculation: unused days × daily salary rate
Calculate daily salary rate: annual gross salary (including prorated extra payments) ÷ 365 calendar days
Check that daily salary rate includes base salary, regular complements, and prorated extra payments
Verify mathematical calculation: unused vacation days × daily salary rate = vacation compensation amount
Compare calculated vacation compensation to amount shown in finiquito document
If calculation is unclear or appears incorrect, request detailed breakdown and explanation
Do not sign finiquito if calculations are disputed; negotiate correction first
If forced to sign under protest, clearly note reservation of rights on finiquito document
If signed finiquito but later discover miscalculation, file labor claim within one year from termination date
Consult union representative or labor lawyer if vacation compensation dispute cannot be resolved directly with employer

bestPractices: Take full annual vacation entitlement each year; vacation provides essential health and wellbeing benefits that cannot be obtained without extended time away from work
Plan at least one extended vacation period (two+ weeks) allowing deep recovery rather than fragmenting all vacation into short periods
Schedule vacation in advance through proper channels providing employer sufficient notice while securing your preferred dates
Genuinely disconnect from work during vacation (do not check work email, do not respond to work calls); digital disconnection is a legal right
Document vacation scheduling (written confirmations), vacation requests, and vacation taken for verification and potential dispute resolution
Assert your right to reschedule vacation lost to documented illness; vacation purpose is recovery and rest, not achievable while ill
Verify vacation compensation calculations at termination carefully before signing final settlement documents
Support collective efforts to promote healthy vacation culture in workplace; individual vacation rights are more secure when vacation usage is normalized and supported rather than stigmatized

glossary.Annual Vacation: Minimum 30 calendar days paid rest entitlement per year; fundamental employment right that cannot be waived or replaced by payment during active employment
glossary.Calendar Days: All days including weekends and public holidays; 30 calendar days approximately equals 22 working days (Mon-Fri)
glossary.Mutual Agreement: Vacation schedule determined through good-faith negotiation between employer and worker considering both preferences and operational needs
glossary.Two-Week Minimum: At least one vacation period must comprise minimum 14 consecutive calendar days; ensures extended recovery period
glossary.Prorated Vacation: Vacation calculated proportionally for partial year employment: (months worked ÷ 12) × 30 days
glossary.Vacation Rescheduling: Right to reschedule vacation days lost to documented illness; vacation purpose frustrated by illness
glossary.Vacation Compensation: Monetary payment for unused vacation at termination only; calculated as daily salary rate × unused vacation days
glossary.Digital Disconnection: Right to not respond to work communications during vacation; protects rest and recovery from work contact interruption
glossary.Finiquito: Final settlement document at termination itemizing all payments including unused vacation compensation; should be verified carefully before signing
